questions.text: A previously healthy 16-year-old boy comes to the physician because of a pruritic rash on the chest that has become progressively larger over the past 10 days. The rash is not painful. He is sexually active with two female partners and uses condoms inconsistently. He works part-time as a lifeguard at a public swimming pool. He has no family history of serious illness. He does not smoke. He drinks five to six beers on weekends. His temperature is 36.7°C (98°F), pulse is 66/min, and blood pressure is 110/70 mm Hg. A photograph of the rash is shown. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Oral amoxicillin is used in the treatment of Lyme disease in pediatric and pregnant/lactating patients. Lyme disease often manifests with an erythematous, circular rash with central clearing. However, the rash is usually characterized by a single annular lesion around the tick bite, is flat without elevated borders, and is not pruritic. Antibiotic treatment is not indicated for the treatment of dermatophyte infections.
Image Description:

Localization: left chest (supramammillary) and axilla
Lesion: erythema
Description: prominent rim of sharply marginated erythema; annular reddening within the right border; no pain or itching.
Diagnosis: erythema chronicum migrans in Lyme disease

B) INCORRECT:

Topical erythromycin is used in the treatment of acne vulgaris and skin infections such as erythrasma, which manifests as scaly, pruritic, hyperpigmented or erythematous patches. However, erythrasma lesions typically appear in intertriginous areas, such as the axilla or groin, and they are not characterized by central clearing.
Image Description:

There is a ∼ 15-cm red-brown, sharply demarcated, distally extending patch in the right groin area, which shows partial scaling.

This is the typical appearance of erythrasma.

C) INCORRECT:

Targeted phototherapy is used in the treatment of some cutaneous diseases, such as psoriasis, which manifests with erythematous, scaly plaques. However, the plaques are usually silvery, occur predominantly on the scalp, elbows, and knees, and do not have central clearing or raised borders.
Image Description:

Multiple sharply demarcated confluent plaques covered with hard, coarse, silver-white scaling are visible over the extensor surface of the knee.

This is the characteristic appearance of plaque psoriasis.

D) CORRECT:

Topical antifungal therapy (e.g., miconazole, terbinafine) is the first-line treatment for most dermatophyte infections, including tinea corporis. Dermatophytes thrive in moist environments, and this patient works at a public swimming pool. Tinea corporis can be diagnosed clinically. In case of diagnostic uncertainty, suspicion of dermatophyte infection is usually confirmed via potassium hydroxide (KOH) preparation.

Systemic antifungal therapy (e.g., oral terbinafine) is used to treat dermatophyte infection in patients who do not respond to topical therapy, immunocompromised individuals, and/or those with extensive spread.

E) INCORRECT:

Topical hydrocortisone is used for a variety of cutaneous conditions, including psoriasis, allergic reactions, and atopic dermatitis. In patients with dermatophyte infections, low-potency corticosteroids (e.g., hydrocortisone) can be used in combination with first-line therapy to accelerate resolution. Topical hydrocortisone is not indicated as a monotherapy for tinea infections.

F) INCORRECT:

This patient's sexual history increases his risk for syphilis, which is treated with penicillin G benzathine. Secondary syphilis typically manifests with cutaneous involvement in the form of a generalized nonpruritic, scaly, papulosquamous rash. However, though the lesions can develop a central clearing, they are usually much smaller than those of tinea corporis.
Image Description:

An erythematous maculopapular rash with scaling is visible on the left palm.

A rash with this appearance typical for secondary syphilis.

G) INCORRECT:

Several dermatological diseases do not require treatment, such as pityriasis rosea. Pityriasis rosea is usually self-limited and can manifest with pruritic scaly plaques and a central clearing. However, lesions are usually preceded by a solitary pink or flesh-colored plaque (known as a herald patch or mother patch) and are not associated with raised borders. Patients with dermatophyte infections, such as tinea corporis, should receive appropriate treatment as well as advice on how to prevent spreading the infection.
Image Description:

A secondary rash after primary plaque formation (not shown) can be seen on the back of this patient. The secondary eruption of pityriasis rosea is usually episodic and distributed along Langer lines.
questions.hint: A pruritic and slowly enlarging rash with erythematous raised scaly borders and central clearing is consistent with tinea corporis.

questions.text: A 9-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his mother because of an itchy rash on the right side of his scalp and progressive loss of hair for 1 month. He has no history of serious illness. His younger sibling was treated for pediculosis capitis 3 months ago. The boy attends elementary school but has not been going for the last week because he has been too embarrassed by the rash. He appears anxious. A photograph of his scalp is shown. Occipital lymphadenopathy is present. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment for this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Shampoo containing zinc pyrithione can be used to treat seborrheic dermatitis, which frequently affects the forehead and/or hairline, cheeks, and scalp and typically manifests with pruritus. However, seborrheic dermatitis lesions typically appear as erythematous plaques with greasy yellow crusts, and patients do not usually experience hair loss. While shampoos containing antifungal substances (e.g., zinc pyrithione) can also be used as an adjunctive measure in patients with tinea capitis to prevent the infection from spreading, they are not an appropriate first-line treatment.
Image Description:

Photograph of a patient’s upper back and neck

Erythematous, partly confluent plaques with silver scaling and greasy crusts are visible.

These findings suggest seborrheic dermatitis.

B) INCORRECT:

Topical mupirocin is one of the treatment options for nonbullous impetigo. While impetigo primarily affects children, it is typically characterized by papules and small vesicles surrounded by erythema on the face and/or extremities. Moreover, impetigo does not cause hair loss.
Image Description:

Confluent erosions and honey-colored crusts with an erythematous base are visible on the face, forehead, temporal region, and part of the neck. As in this photo, vesicles may not always be present or noticeable.

C) INCORRECT:

Triamcinolone may be used intradermally to treat alopecia areata (spot baldness), which manifests with smooth, rounded patches of hair loss. Alopecia areata does not, however, cause pruritus.
Image Description:

There are well-demarcated, patchy areas of hair loss without scarring of the scalp.

D) CORRECT:

Systemic antifungal therapy (e.g., oral griseofulvin, oral terbinafine) is the first-line treatment for patients with tinea capitis. While topical formulations can be used to treat most mild dermatophyte infections (e.g., tinea corporis), they are unable to penetrate the hair shaft and, therefore, are often ineffective at treating tinea capitis. Shampoos containing antifungal substances (e.g., ketoconazole) are used as an adjunctive measure to prevent the infection from spreading. In addition, patients should avoid close personal contact and sharing of potentially contaminated objects (e.g., combs).

Diagnosis is established using potassium hydroxide (KOH) preparation or fungal culture.

E) INCORRECT:

Topical permethrin is one of the treatment options for pediculosis capitis, which is caused by head lice infestation. The condition frequently causes severe pruritus of the head in children, but it does not cause hair loss.
Image Description:

A single head louse is visible on this child's scalp.

F) INCORRECT:

Topical calcipotriene may be used to treat mild to moderate psoriasis. Psoriasis may also present with plaques on the scalp, but they are clearly demarcated and erythematous with silvery scaling and also affect the back, elbows, and/or knees (extensor surfaces), unlike in this patient.
Image Description:

Multiple round, sharply demarcated, scaly, erythematous plaques are visible on the arms and trunk.

This appearance is typical of guttate psoriasis, a subtype of psoriasis.
questions.hint: Pruritic scaly plaques with broken hair shafts and areas of alopecia suggest tinea capitis, a contagious infection that typically occurs in children. Regional lymphadenopathy is a common finding in patients with this condition.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man comes to the physician because of a rash on the thigh for 10 days. He reports that the rash has been enlarging and is intensely itchy. Two weeks ago, he adopted a stray dog from an animal shelter. Vital signs are within normal limits. A photograph of the examination findings is shown. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Psoriasis is a chronic condition that causes pruritic, erythematous, well-demarcated plaques. However, the lesions are typically covered in silver-white scale and distributed bilaterally, classically on the extensor surfaces of the knees and elbows. Psoriasis does not typically manifest on the thigh with a solitary, annular plaque with central clearing and a raised border.
Image Description:

Multiple sharply demarcated confluent plaques covered with hard, coarse, silver-white scaling are visible over the extensor surface of the knee.

This is the characteristic appearance of plaque psoriasis.

B) INCORRECT:

Erythrasma can cause pruritic, well-demarcated lesions. However, the lesions are typically hyperpigmented, macular, and more commonly develop in intertriginous areas (e.g., the axillae and groin). Erythrasma does not typically manifest on the thigh with a solitary, erythematous, annular plaque with central clearing and a raised border.
Image Description:

Right side of the scrotum

Lesion: reddish-brown, sharply demarcated macula

Diagnosis: erythrasma

C) INCORRECT:

Scabies can cause pruritic, erythematous, well-demarcated lesions. However, the lesions typically manifest as elongated papules and scattered vesicles with burrows tunneled by the Sarcoptes scabiei mite and more commonly develop on the hands. Scabies does not typically manifest on the thigh as a solitary, erythematous, annular plaque with central clearing and a raised border.
Image Description:

Multiple erythematous papules can be seen in the interdigital folds between the index and middle finger.

Interdigital folds are a common site for scabies, as the scabies mite prefers warmer skin regions with a thin keratinous layer.

D) INCORRECT:

Pityriasis rosea can cause pruritic plaques with a collarette of scale that yields an annular appearance. However, the initial lesion of pityriasis rosea is a herald patch, which most commonly manifests on the back as a solitary, ovoid, hyperpigmented macule or patch with a slightly raised, erythematous border and a collarette of fine scale. In contrast, this patient has a solitary lesion on the thigh with geographic borders. In addition, following the herald patch of pityriasis rosea, patients typically develop multiple papules and plaques on the back that are distributed along the lines of skin cleavage (i.e., the Langer lines), which results in a characteristic pattern that appears like the outline of a Christmas tree.
Image Description:

Initial eruption (herald patch) and secondary eruption on the trunk

The herald patch (black arrow) is ovoid with a raised dark border and central clearing. The secondary eruption consists of scattered papules and plaques on an erythematous base.

E) CORRECT:

This patient has a dermatophyte infection, a common fungal infection of the skin, hair, and/or nails transmitted via contact with the skin of an infected person or animal (e.g., this patient's recently adopted dog). Dermatophyte infections can affect the scalp (tinea capitis), inguinal area (tinea cruris), hands (tinea manuum), feet (tinea pedis), nails (tinea unguium), or rest of the body (tinea corporis). Tinea corporis is most commonly caused by Trichophyton rubrum and classically spreads centrifugally, manifesting with an erythematous, annular, and pruritic plaque with central clearing and a raised border. The diagnosis can be confirmed by obtaining scale from a lesion and visualizing branching, septate hyphae on a KOH test. Antifungal treatment options include topical azoles (e.g., ketoconazole) or systemic agents (e.g., oral terbinafine) for extensive and/or refractory disease.
Image Description:

Wet mount of scraped skin stained with 20% KOH solution, which dissolves keratinocytes. While this method makes fungal elements easily visible, it does not allow for differentiation between different types of fungi (dermatophytes, yeast, etc).

F) INCORRECT:

Tinea versicolor can cause pruritic, well-demarcated lesions. However, the lesions are typically hypopigmented or hyperpigmented, macular, and more commonly develop on the trunk and chest, not the extremities. Tinea versicolor does not typically manifest on the thigh with a solitary, erythematous, annular plaque with central clearing and a raised border.
Image Description:

Numerous hypopigmented, well-demarcated macules are visible on the patient's back. The lesions show fine scaling and coalesce in some regions.

This is the typical appearance of pityriasis versicolor.
questions.hint: The photograph shows an erythematous, annular plaque with central clearing and a raised border.

questions.text:
A 28-year-old man presents with a pruritic eruption on his left posterior calf. He is otherwise healthy and has no systemic concerns. He works as both a bicycle courier and a dog walker and reports no unusual exposures or bites. He reports that the rash started as one small scaly area and has expanded during the past several weeks.
An annular configuration of erythematous papules with fine peripheral scaling is visible on the left posterior calf (figure); there is an adjacent smaller annular, scaly, thin plaque on the lateral shin. No pustules are present, and the rest of the physical examination is unremarkable.
Which one of the following treatments is most appropriate in this case?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Doxycycline is the treatment of choice for Lyme disease, which can manifest with an annular skin lesion (erythema chronicum migrans). A KOH preparation, fungal culture, and if necessary, a skin biopsy can readily distinguish between erythema chronicum migrans and tinea corporis. Erythema chronicum migrans generally lacks scale, which is an important diagnostic clue for tinea, and the plaque itself is usually contiguous without areas of sparing between papules.

B) INCORRECT:

Nystatin is effective at treating candida species but not dermatophytes. Candidal infection is common on the skin, and sites of dermatophyte infection in the skin folds also frequently harbor candida. Candidal infection typically manifests with intertriginous erythema, which will often display satellite lesions (small papules and pustules scattered outward from the edge of the central erythema). Candidal infection will frequently involve the scrotum, whereas dermatophyte infection rarely extends to affect that anatomic site. Azoles and terbinafine (and related compounds) can treat both candida species and dermatophytes, whereas nystatin has narrower coverage that includes only candida.

C) CORRECT:

This patient has a pruritic, annular, erythematous eruption with scale that seems to be expanding outward. Although numerous cutaneous eruptions can present with pinkish-red inflammation, the annular nature of this particular pruritic eruption coupled with the active border and fine scale along the leading edge suggests a diagnosis of potential dermatophyte infection.

Tinea corporis is the specific name given to a superficial dermatophyte infection on the skin of the body, as opposed to the scalp (tinea capitis), foot (tinea pedis), or other area. It typically appears violaceous or hyperpigmented on dark skin and pinkish-red on light skin.

The presence of hyphae in a skin scraping observed with light microscopy after application of potassium hydroxide (KOH) can confirm the diagnosis of a tinea infection. Dermatophyte culture may also be performed for definitive diagnosis and speciation of the organism, but it is generally not required for tinea corporis unless there are unusual clinical circumstances or the KOH scraping is negative.

Tinea corporis typically responds to topical therapy with either azoles or allylamines, such as terbinafine. Terbinafine and related agents appear to have the greatest efficacy. Importantly, if pustules or deep red papules are present, this suggests fungal folliculitis (Majocchi granuloma), which corresponds to infection within the hair follicle. Follicular involvement often requires systemic therapy to cure the infection because topical treatments may not adequately penetrate the hair follicle.

Key learning point: The recommended treatment for tinea corporis is a topical azole or allylamine medication, such as terbinafine.

D) INCORRECT:

Topical glucocorticoids, such as hydrocortisone, may transiently improve the pruritus and erythema associated with tinea corporis. However, these medications can exacerbate the infection, possibly leading to deeper infection (including Majocchi granuloma), and may change the clinical appearance of the infection (Tinea incognito).

E) INCORRECT:

Oral glucocorticoids, such as methylprednisolone, are not indicated for the treatment of fungal infections.

questions.text:
A 27-year-old woman reports a flaky, dry rash on the soles of both feet. Applying unscented lotion to the affected areas has yielded no improvement.
Visual inspection reveals scaly, dry patches and collarettes of scale on the soles of both feet (figure). Maceration and a superficial fissure are evident between the fourth and fifth digits on the left foot. No other skin lesions are evident, and there is no involvement of the toenails.
Which one of the following treatments is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: Thick moisturizer applied twice daily to the affected area until the rash resolves
Terbinafine applied topically twice daily to the affected area until the rash resolves
1% hydrocortisone cream applied twice daily to the affected area until the rash resolves
Mineral oil applied to the affected area until the rash resolves

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

An oral antifungal, such as systemic terbinafine or fluconazole, may occasionally be used to treat severe or refractory cutaneous fungal infections, or if there is involvement of the nails, but a topical antifungal is indicated for first-line treatment.

B) INCORRECT:

A thick moisturizer can be used as an adjuvant emollient in the treatment of atopic dermatitis but is not a treatment for tinea pedis.

C) CORRECT:

Tinea is a fungal infection caused by aerobic dermatophytes that infect only the epidermal layer of the skin. Risk factors include warm, moist environments; shoe wearing; and exposure to affected individuals or to fomites such as exercise mats, locker room floors, bathtubs, or shower stalls.

Tinea pedis typically manifests as superficial maceration between the toes or as exfoliating skin on the plantar surface of the foot, but it may also manifest as dry, scaly lesions on the dorsum of the foot characterized by collarettes of scale (little scaly circles). The latter pattern, often caused by Trichophyton rubrum, may mimic atopic dermatitis; however, atopic dermatitis would not be limited to the foot. Tinea may infect inflamed, disrupted skin of patients with atopic dermatitis. There may be associated pruritus. The correct diagnosis can be confirmed by identifying fungal hyphae on microscopic examination of lesional scrapings that are prepared with potassium hydroxide (KOH) solution, although this is rarely necessary.

First-line treatment for uncomplicated tinea pedis limited to the skin is a topical antifungal agent, such as terbinafine. Other topical agents, such as an azole (clotrimazole, ketoconazole), can also be used, but studies suggest that allylamines (terbinafine and naftifine) have superior efficacy; both classes perform better than placebo.

In addition to using a topical antifungal, patients with tinea pedis should be advised to keep their feet dry and to use cotton or moisture-wicking socks that breathe sufficiently.

Key learning point: The first-line treatment for tinea pedis is a topical antifungal agent, such as terbinafine.

D) INCORRECT:

The use of 1% hydrocortisone, with an adjuvant emollient like mineral oil or other thick moisturizer, would be appropriate for atopic dermatitis, but it has little role in the treatment of fungal dermatitis and may worsen tinea pedis.

E) INCORRECT:

Mineral oil can be used as an adjuvant emollient in the treatment of atopic dermatitis but is not a treatment for tinea pedis.

questions.text:
A 55-year-old man reports thickening and yellowing of several toenails for the past 2 years. He says that the nails snag on clothing and linens but are not painful. He also reports itchiness along the soles of his feet. He has not tried any treatments at home. He has a history of hypertension for which he takes hydrochlorothiazide.
On examination, he has thickened, yellowed toenails with subungual debris (figure). Scaling and erythema are evident along the soles of his feet.
Which one of the following diagnoses is most likely in this case?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Trachyonychia is characterized by rough, brittle nails that are often likened to sandpaper. It is more common in children and in patients with inflammatory skin disorders and would not manifest with thickening and yellowing of the nails.

B) INCORRECT:

Onycholysis refers to the lifting of the nail plate off the nail bed and can be caused by a variety of conditions, including trauma. However, it is less likely in this case due to the absence of reported trauma, the long duration of symptoms, and the involvement of several toenails.

C) INCORRECT:

Psoriasis can cause a variety of nail disorders, including onycholysis, but the coexistence of tinea pedis in this case is more suggestive of an infectious process, such as onychomycosis, than psoriasis.

D) CORRECT:

This patient has onychomycosis, a fungal nail infection that leads to thickening and yellowing of the nail plate. In some cases, it may also cause onycholysis, or lifting of the nail plate from the nail bed. Given that this patient has scaling, erythema, and itchiness of the soles of his feet, he probably also has tinea pedis, which commonly coexists with onychomycosis. Onychomycosis can affect any nail but most often involves the toenails.

The most common pathogen to cause distal subungual onychomycosis is the dermatophyte Trichophyton rubrum. Diagnosis should be confirmed with nail-clipping culture and histology before treatment is initiated. Oral antifungal treatment with terbinafine or itraconazole is superior to topical treatment, although an extended course is usually required. Recurrences after treatment are common.

Key learning point: Onychomycosis is a fungal infection of the nails that manifests with nail-plate thickening, yellowing, and lifting from the nail bed, often in a patient with concomitant tinea pedis.

E) INCORRECT:

Chronic paronychia occurs when the nail fold around the nail plate becomes chronically inflamed. This condition manifests with erythema and edema of the skin around the nail.

questions.text:
A 21-year-old woman reports a rash on her chest that has been present for the past 2 weeks. She reports that it began as a small, scaly papule that has progressively expanded and is mildly pruritic. She has not tried any treatments. She is otherwise healthy, is not pregnant, and takes no medications. She mentions that her 3-year-old son has had scaling and alopecia on his scalp for the past 2 months but has not yet been treated.
Examination reveals an erythematous scaly plaque on the chest (figure). A potassium hydroxide (KOH) preparation of a scraping from the periphery of the lesion reveals hyphal forms.
Which one of the following treatments is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: Clotrimazole 1% cream compounded with betamethasone dipropionate 0.05% cream

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Nystatin, an anti-yeast medication, does not treat dermatophytes.

B) INCORRECT:

Hydrocortisone and other topical glucocorticoids do not treat fungal infections. Although topical glucocorticoids may diminish the erythema and pruritus of the rash, the infection often spreads with use, even if the topical glucocorticoid is combined with a topical antifungal agent.

C) INCORRECT:

Systemic agents such as oral terbinafine, itraconazole, and griseofulvin are usually reserved for patients with extensive disease affecting large body-surface areas; infections extending down hair follicles, such as tinea capitis or Majocchi granuloma; or infections that have proven to be refractory to consistent use of topical antifungals for at least several weeks.

D) CORRECT:

Annular scaly plaques are a hallmark of dermatophyte fungal infections, including tinea corporis. These infections usually affect children and young adults and are sometimes confused with seborrheic dermatitis or sebopsoriasis. Adults are most typically affected through exposure to children (such as this patient’s son, who probably has tinea capitis) or to soil or animals.

In adults, treatment of a superficial dermatophyte infection generally starts with a topical antifungal agent such as a topical azole or topical terbinafine and should be continued until the visible rash and pruritus resolve. Systemic agents such as oral terbinafine, itraconazole, and griseofulvin are usually reserved for patients with extensive disease affecting large body-surface areas; infections extending down hair follicles, such as tinea capitis or Majocchi granuloma; or infections that have proven to be refractory to consistent use of topical antifungals for at least several weeks.

Key learning point: The first-line treatment for superficial dermatophyte infection in an adult is usually a topical antifungal agent such as clotrimazole 1% cream.

E) INCORRECT:

Topical glucocorticoids, including betamethasone dipropionate, do not treat fungal infections. Although topical glucocorticoids may diminish the erythema and pruritus of the rash, the infection often spreads with use, even if the topical glucocorticoid is combined with a topical antifungal agent.

questions.text:
A 15-year-old girl reports a flaky, dry rash on the soles of both feet. Applying unscented lotion to the affected areas has yielded no improvement.
Visual inspection reveals scaly, dry patches and collarettes of scale on the soles of both feet (figure). Maceration and a superficial fissure are evident between the fourth and fifth digits on the left foot. No other skin lesions are evident, and there is no involvement of the toenails.
Which one of the following treatments is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: Mineral oil applied to the affected area until the rash resolves
Thick moisturizer applied twice daily to the affected area until the rash resolves
1% hydrocortisone cream applied twice daily to the affected area until the rash resolves
Terbinafine cream applied topically twice daily to the affected area until the rash resolves

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

An oral antifungal, such as systemic terbinafine or fluconazole, may occasionally be used to treat severe or refractory cutaneous fungal infections, or if there is involvement of the nails, but a topical antifungal is indicated for first-line treatment.

B) INCORRECT:

Mineral oil can be used as an adjuvant emollient in the treatment of atopic dermatitis but is not a treatment for tinea pedis.

C) INCORRECT:

A thick moisturizer can be used as an adjuvant emollient in the treatment of atopic dermatitis but is not a treatment for tinea pedis.

D) INCORRECT:

The use of 1% hydrocortisone, with an adjuvant emollient like mineral oil or other thick moisturizer, would be appropriate for atopic dermatitis, but it has little role in the treatment of fungal dermatitis.

E) CORRECT:

Tinea is a fungal infection caused by aerobic dermatophytes that infect only the epidermal layer of the skin. Tinea pedis tends to occur in older children but may also be observed in infants. Risk factors include warm, moist, macerated environments, shoe wearing, and exposure to affected individuals or to fomites such as exercise mats, locker room floors, bathtubs, or shower stalls.

Tinea pedis typically manifests as superficial maceration between the toes or as exfoliating skin on the plantar surface of the foot, but it may also manifest as dry, scaly lesions on the dorsum of the foot characterized by collarettes of scale (little scaly circles). The latter pattern, often caused by Trichophyton rubrum, may mimic atopic dermatitis; however, atopic dermatitis would not be limited to the foot. Tinea may infect inflamed, disrupted skin of patients with atopic dermatitis. There may be associated pruritus. The correct diagnosis can be confirmed by identifying fungal hyphae on microscopic examination of lesional scrapings that are prepared with potassium hydroxide (KOH) solution.

First-line treatment for uncomplicated tinea pedis limited to the skin is a topical antifungal agent, such as terbinafine. Other topical agents, such as an azole (clotrimazole, ketoconazole), can also be used, but studies suggest that allylamines (terbinafine and naftifine) have superior efficacy; both classes perform better than placebo.

In addition to using a topical antifungal, patients with tinea pedis should be advised to keep their feet dry and to use cotton or moisture-wicking socks that breathe sufficiently.

Key learning point: The first-line treatment for tinea pedis is a topical antifungal agent, such as terbinafine.

questions.text:
A 5-year-old boy presents for evaluation of scaly, hairless patches on his scalp that his mother noticed 2 days ago while she was giving him a haircut.
Physical examination reveals a 6-cm scaly, alopecic patch with central black dots and excoriations on the patient’s right parietal scalp (figure) and a similar crusted lesion on the vertex scalp. The patient also has posterior cervical lymphadenopathy.
Which one of the following treatments is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: Topical 2.5% hydrocortisone ointment twice daily for 2 weeks
Oral amoxicillin twice daily for 10 days
Selenium sulfide shampoo daily for 2 weeks
Topical clotrimazole twice daily for 2 weeks
Oral griseofulvin daily for 8 to 12 weeks

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Topical glucocorticoids, such as 2.5% hydrocortisone ointment, are ineffective for the treatment of tinea capitis. They may be helpful for seborrheic dermatitis, but when this condition occurs on the scalp, it usually manifests with localized scalp scale without associated alopecia or lymphadenopathy.

B) INCORRECT:

Oral antibiotics, such as amoxicillin, are ineffective for the treatment of tinea capitis.

C) INCORRECT:

Topical antifungal therapies (including clotrimazole and selenium sulfide) are inadequate as monotherapy for tinea capitis because they cannot penetrate the subcutaneous portion of the hair follicle where the fungus also resides. Clotrimazole is often used as first-line therapy for tinea corporis, and selenium sulfide can be used to treat tinea versicolor and seborrheic dermatitis.

D) INCORRECT:

Topical antifungal therapies (including clotrimazole and selenium sulfide) are inadequate as monotherapy for tinea capitis because they cannot penetrate the subcutaneous portion of the hair follicle where the fungus also resides. Clotrimazole is often used as first-line therapy for tinea corporis, and selenium sulfide can be used to treat tinea versicolor and seborrheic dermatitis.

E) CORRECT:

Tinea capitis is a dermatophyte fungal infection of the scalp. In the United States, it is typically caused by Trichophyton tonsurans and, less commonly, Microsporum species; it most often affects children aged 3 to 9 years.

The gold standard for diagnosis of tinea capitis is a dermatophyte culture from scrapings of a scalp lesion. The diagnosis can also be made by identifying spores on an affected hair shaft with microscopic potassium hydroxide (KOH) examination. Confirming the diagnosis is important before initiating systemic treatment because several other conditions may mimic the clinical appearance of tinea capitis, including seborrheic dermatitis, psoriasis, and eczema.

Eruptions caused by tinea capitis can appear as areas of mild scaling, circular areas of alopecia (with black dots in the center that represent broken-off infected hair remnants), or boggy areas of inflammation with associated exudate (kerion). Affected children will often have posterior cervical lymphadenopathy, although this is not a specific sign.

Systemic antifungal therapy, such as oral griseofulvin, is required to adequately treat tinea infections that involve hair-bearing sites such as the scalp. Eight to twelve weeks of therapy is needed to achieve clinical resolution, and microbiologic cure can be assured with a repeat culture obtained about 8 weeks into therapy. If the culture is negative, treatment may be stopped. If it is positive, treatment is often continued another 2 to 4 weeks depending on the clinical context.

Randomized trials have examined the efficacy of other systemic antifungals such as terbinafine, fluconazole, and itraconazole for the treatment of tinea capitis. These agents appear to be as effective as griseofulvin (or more so) and, given increasing resistance to griseofulvin, are becoming first-line choices to treat tinea capitis in children.

Key learning point: The most appropriate treatment for children with tinea capitis (ringworm of the scalp) is systemic griseofulvin.

questions.text:
A 16-year-old boy presents with a pruritic eruption on his left posterior calf. He is otherwise healthy and has no systemic complaints. He works on the weekends as a dog walker and reports no unusual exposures or bites. He reports that the rash started as one small scaly area and has expanded during the past several weeks.
A palm-sized erythematous patch comprised of multiple concentric rings with very fine peripheral scaling is visible on the left posterior calf (figure); there is an adjacent smaller annular, scaly, thin plaque on the lateral shin. There are no pustules, and the rest of the physical examination is unremarkable.
Which one of the following treatments is most appropriate in this case?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Doxycycline is the treatment of choice for Lyme disease, which can manifest with an annular skin lesion (erythema chronicum migrans). Erythema chronicum migrans generally lacks scale, which is an important diagnostic clue for tinea.

B) CORRECT:

This patient has a pruritic, annular, erythematous eruption with scale that seems to be expanding outward. Although numerous cutaneous eruptions can present with pinkish-red inflammation, the annular nature of this particular pruritic eruption coupled with the active border and fine scale suggests a diagnosis of potential dermatophyte infection. Tinea corporis is the specific name given to a superficial dermatophyte infection on the skin of the body, as opposed to the scalp (tinea capitis), foot (tinea pedis), or other area. It typically appears violaceous on dark skin and pinkish-red on light skin. The presence of hyphae in a skin scraping observed with light microscopy after application of potassium hydroxide (KOH) can confirm the diagnosis of a tinea infection. Dermatophyte culture may also be performed for definitive diagnosis and speciation of the organism, but it is generally not required for tinea corporis unless there are unusual clinical circumstances or the KOH scraping is negative.

Tinea corporis typically responds to topical therapy with either azoles or allylamines, such as terbinafine. Terbinafine and related agents appear to have the greatest efficacy. Importantly, if pustules or deep red papules are present, this suggests fungal folliculitis (Majocchi granuloma), which corresponds to infection within the hair follicle. Follicular involvement often requires systemic therapy to cure the infection because topical treatments may not adequately penetrate the hair follicle.

Key learning point: The recommended route for administering antifungal treatment to a patient with tinea corporis is topical.

C) INCORRECT:

Nystatin is effective at treating candida species but not dermatophytes. Candidal infection is common on the skin, and sites of dermatophyte infection in the skin folds also frequently harbor candida. Candidal infection typically manifests with intertriginous erythema, which will often display satellite lesions (small papules scattered outward from the edge of the central erythema). Pinpoint pustules are also common. Candidal infection will frequently involve the scrotum, whereas dermatophyte infection rarely extends to affect that anatomic site. Azoles and terbinafine (and related compounds) can treat both candida species and dermatophytes, whereas nystatin has narrower coverage that includes only candida.

D) INCORRECT:

Oral glucocorticoids, such as methylprednisolone, are not indicated for the treatment of fungal infections.

E) INCORRECT:

Topical glucocorticoids, such as hydrocortisone, may transiently improve the pruritus and erythema associated with tinea corporis, but these medications can exacerbate the infection and may even lead to deeper infection (including Majocchi granuloma).

questions.text: A 55-year-old man reports thickening and yellowing of several toenails for the past 2 years. He says that the nails snag on clothing and linens but are not painful. He also reports itchiness along the soles of his feet. On examination, he has thickened, yellowed toenails with subungual debris (figure). Scaling and erythema are evident along the soles of his feet. Which one of the following diagnoses is most likely in this case?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Trachyonychia is characterized by rough, brittle nails that are often likened to sandpaper. It is more common in children and in patients with inflammatory skin disorders and would not manifest with thickening and yellowing of the nails.

B) INCORRECT:

Onycholysis refers to the lifting of the nail plate off the nail bed and can be caused by a variety of conditions, including trauma. However, it is less likely in this case due to the absence of reported trauma, the long duration of symptoms, and the involvement of several toenails.

C) INCORRECT:

Psoriasis can cause a variety of nail disorders, including onycholysis, but the coexistence of tinea pedis in this case is more suggestive of an infectious process than psoriasis.

D) CORRECT:

This patient has onychomycosis, a fungal nail infection that leads to thickening and yellowing of the nail plate. In some cases, it may also cause onycholysis, or lifting of the nail plate from the nail bed. Given that this patient has scaling, erythema, and itchiness of the soles of his feet, he probably also has tinea pedis, which commonly coexists with onychomycosis. Onychomycosis can affect any nail but most often involves the toenails.

The most common pathogen to cause distal subungual onychomycosis is the dermatophyte Trichophyton rubrum. Diagnosis should be confirmed with nail-clipping culture and histology before treatment is initiated. Oral antifungal treatment with terbinafine or itraconazole is superior to topical treatment, although an extended course is usually required. Recurrences after treatment are common.

Key learning point: Onychomycosis is a fungal infection of the nails that manifests with nail-plate thickening, yellowing, and lifting from the nail bed, often in a patient with concomitant tinea pedis.

E) INCORRECT:

Chronic paronychia occurs when the nail fold around the nail plate becomes chronically inflamed. This condition manifests with erythema and edema of the skin around the nail.

questions.text: A previously healthy 16-year-old boy comes to the office because of a pruritic rash on the chest that has become progressively larger over the past 10 days. The rash is not painful. He is sexually active with two female partners and uses condoms inconsistently. He works part-time as a lifeguard at a public swimming pool. A photograph of the rash is shown. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Topical erythromycin is used in the treatment of acne vulgaris and skin infections such as erythrasma, which manifests as scaly, pruritic, hyperpigmented or erythematous patches. However, erythrasma lesions typically appear in intertriginous areas, such as the axilla or groin, and they are not characterized by central clearing.
Image Description:

There is a ∼ 15-cm red-brown, sharply demarcated, distally extending patch in the right groin area, which shows partial scaling.

This is the typical appearance of erythrasma.

B) CORRECT:

Topical antifungal therapy (e.g., miconazole, terbinafine) is the first-line treatment for most dermatophyte infections, including tinea corporis. Dermatophytes thrive in moist environments, and this patient works at a public swimming pool. Tinea corporis can be diagnosed clinically. In case of diagnostic uncertainty, suspicion of dermatophyte infection is usually confirmed via potassium hydroxide (KOH) preparation.

Systemic antifungal therapy (e.g., oral terbinafine) is used to treat dermatophyte infection in patients who do not respond to topical therapy, immunocompromised individuals, and/or those with extensive spread.

C) INCORRECT:

Topical hydrocortisone is used for a variety of cutaneous conditions, including psoriasis, allergic reactions, and atopic dermatitis. In patients with dermatophyte infections, low-potency corticosteroids (e.g., hydrocortisone) can be used in combination with first-line therapy to accelerate resolution. Topical hydrocortisone is not indicated as a monotherapy for tinea infections.

D) INCORRECT:

This patient's sexual history increases his risk for syphilis, which is treated with penicillin G benzathine. Secondary syphilis typically manifests with cutaneous involvement in the form of a generalized nonpruritic, scaly, papulosquamous rash. However, though the lesions can develop a central clearing, they are usually much smaller than those of tinea corporis.
Image Description:

An erythematous maculopapular rash with scaling is visible on the left palm.

A rash with this appearance typical for secondary syphilis.

E) INCORRECT:

Several dermatological diseases do not require treatment, such as pityriasis rosea. Pityriasis rosea is usually self-limited and can manifest with pruritic scaly plaques and a central clearing. However, lesions are usually preceded by a solitary pink or flesh-colored plaque (known as a herald patch or mother patch) and are not associated with raised borders. Patients with dermatophyte infections, such as tinea corporis, should receive appropriate treatment as well as advice on how to prevent spreading the infection.
Image Description:

A secondary rash after primary plaque formation (not shown) can be seen on the back of this patient. The secondary eruption of pityriasis rosea is usually episodic and distributed along Langer lines.
questions.hint: A pruritic and slowly enlarging rash with erythematous raised scaly borders and central clearing is consistent with tinea corporis.

questions.text: A 9-year-old boy is brought to the office by his mother because of an itchy rash on the right side of his scalp and progressive loss of hair for 1 month. His younger sibling was treated for pediculosis capitis 3 months ago. The boy attends elementary school but has not been going for the last week because he has been too embarrassed by the rash. A photograph of his scalp is shown. Occipital lymphadenopathy is present. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment for this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Shampoo containing zinc pyrithione can be used to treat seborrheic dermatitis, which frequently affects the forehead and/or hairline, cheeks, and scalp and typically manifests with pruritus. However, seborrheic dermatitis lesions typically appear as erythematous plaques with greasy yellow crusts, and patients do not usually experience hair loss. While shampoos containing antifungal substances (e.g., zinc pyrithione) can also be used as an adjunctive measure in patients with tinea capitis to prevent the infection from spreading, they are not an appropriate first-line treatment.
Image Description:

Photograph of a patient’s upper back and neck

Erythematous, partly confluent plaques with silver scaling and greasy crusts are visible.

These findings suggest seborrheic dermatitis.

B) INCORRECT:

Topical mupirocin is one of the treatment options for nonbullous impetigo. While impetigo primarily affects children, it is typically characterized by papules and small vesicles surrounded by erythema on the face and/or extremities. Moreover, impetigo does not cause hair loss.
Image Description:

Confluent erosions and honey-colored crusts with an erythematous base are visible on the face, forehead, temporal region, and part of the neck. As in this photo, vesicles may not always be present or noticeable.

C) INCORRECT:

Triamcinolone may be used intradermally to treat alopecia areata (spot baldness), which manifests with smooth, rounded patches of hair loss. Alopecia areata does not, however, cause pruritus.
Image Description:

There are well-demarcated, patchy areas of hair loss without scarring of the scalp.

D) CORRECT:

Systemic antifungal therapy (e.g., oral griseofulvin, oral terbinafine) is the first-line treatment for patients with tinea capitis. While topical formulations can be used to treat most mild dermatophyte infections (e.g., tinea corporis), they are unable to penetrate the hair shaft and, therefore, are often ineffective at treating tinea capitis. Shampoos containing antifungal substances (e.g., ketoconazole) are used as an adjunctive measure to prevent the infection from spreading. In addition, patients should avoid close personal contact and sharing of potentially contaminated objects (e.g., combs).

Diagnosis is established using potassium hydroxide (KOH) preparation or fungal culture.

E) INCORRECT:

Topical permethrin is one of the treatment options for pediculosis capitis, which is caused by head lice infestation. The condition frequently causes severe pruritus of the head in children, but it does not cause hair loss.
Image Description:

A single head louse is visible on this child's scalp.
questions.hint: Pruritic scaly plaques with broken hair shafts and areas of alopecia suggest tinea capitis, a contagious infection that typically occurs in children. Regional lymphadenopathy is a common finding in patients with this condition.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man comes to the office because of a rash on the thigh for 10 days. He reports that the rash has been enlarging and is intensely itchy. Two weeks ago, he adopted a stray dog from an animal shelter. Vital signs are within normal limits. A photograph of the examination findings is shown. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Erythrasma can cause pruritic, well-demarcated lesions. However, the lesions are typically hyperpigmented, macular, and more commonly develop in intertriginous areas (e.g., the axillae and groin). Erythrasma does not typically manifest on the thigh with a solitary, erythematous, annular plaque with central clearing and a raised border.
Image Description:

Right side of the scrotum

Lesion: reddish-brown, sharply demarcated macula

Diagnosis: erythrasma

B) INCORRECT:

Scabies can cause pruritic, erythematous, well-demarcated lesions. However, the lesions typically manifest as elongated papules and scattered vesicles with burrows tunneled by the Sarcoptes scabiei mite and more commonly develop on the hands. Scabies does not typically manifest on the thigh as a solitary, erythematous, annular plaque with central clearing and a raised border.
Image Description:

Multiple erythematous papules can be seen in the interdigital folds between the index and middle finger.

Interdigital folds are a common site for scabies, as the scabies mite prefers warmer skin regions with a thin keratinous layer.

C) INCORRECT:

Pityriasis rosea can cause pruritic plaques with a collarette of scale that yields an annular appearance. However, the initial lesion of pityriasis rosea is a herald patch, which most commonly manifests on the back as a solitary, ovoid, hyperpigmented macule or patch with a slightly raised, erythematous border and a collarette of fine scale. In contrast, this patient has a solitary lesion on the thigh with geographic borders. In addition, following the herald patch of pityriasis rosea, patients typically develop multiple papules and plaques on the back that are distributed along the lines of skin cleavage (i.e., the Langer lines), which results in a characteristic pattern that appears like the outline of a Christmas tree.
Image Description:

Initial eruption (herald patch) and secondary eruption on the trunk

The herald patch (black arrow) is ovoid with a raised dark border and central clearing. The secondary eruption consists of scattered papules and plaques on an erythematous base.

D) CORRECT:

This patient has a dermatophyte infection, a common fungal infection of the skin, hair, and/or nails transmitted via contact with the skin of an infected person or animal (e.g., this patient's recently adopted dog). Dermatophyte infections can affect the scalp (tinea capitis), inguinal area (tinea cruris), hands (tinea manuum), feet (tinea pedis), nails (tinea unguium), or rest of the body (tinea corporis). Tinea corporis is most commonly caused by Trichophyton rubrum and classically spreads centrifugally, manifesting with an erythematous, annular, and pruritic plaque with central clearing and a raised border. The diagnosis can be confirmed by obtaining scale from a lesion and visualizing branching, septate hyphae on a KOH test. Antifungal treatment options include topical azoles (e.g., ketoconazole) or systemic agents (e.g., oral terbinafine) for extensive and/or refractory disease.

Key learning point: Dermatophyte infections present as pruritic, annular plaques with central clearing and a raised, scaly border, often following contact with infected people or animals.
Image Description:

Wet mount of scraped skin stained with 20% KOH solution, which dissolves keratinocytes. While this method makes fungal elements easily visible, it does not allow for differentiation between different types of fungi (dermatophytes, yeast, etc).

E) INCORRECT:

Tinea versicolor can cause pruritic, well-demarcated lesions. However, the lesions are typically hypopigmented or hyperpigmented, macular, and more commonly develop on the trunk and chest, not the extremities. Tinea versicolor does not typically manifest on the thigh with a solitary, erythematous, annular plaque with central clearing and a raised border.
Image Description:

Numerous hypopigmented, well-demarcated macules are visible on the patient's back. The lesions show fine scaling and coalesce in some regions.

This is the typical appearance of pityriasis versicolor.
questions.hint: The photograph shows an erythematous, annular plaque with central clearing and a raised border.

questions.text: A 27-year-old woman reports a flaky, dry rash on the soles of both feet. Visual inspection reveals scaly, dry patches and collarettes of scale on the soles of both feet (figure). Maceration and a superficial fissure are evident between the fourth and fifth digits on the left foot. No other skin lesions are evident, and there is no involvement of the toenails. Which one of the following treatments is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: Thick moisturizer applied to the affected area
Mineral oil applied to the affected area

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

An oral antifungal, such as systemic terbinafine or fluconazole, may occasionally be used to treat severe or refractory cutaneous fungal infections, or if there is involvement of the nails, but a topical antifungal is indicated for first-line treatment.

B) INCORRECT:

A thick moisturizer can be used as an adjuvant emollient in the treatment of atopic dermatitis but is not a treatment for tinea pedis.

C) CORRECT:

Tinea is a fungal infection caused by aerobic dermatophytes that infect only the epidermal layer of the skin. Risk factors include warm, moist environments; shoe wearing; and exposure to affected individuals or to fomites such as exercise mats, locker room floors, bathtubs, or shower stalls.

Tinea pedis typically manifests as superficial maceration between the toes or as exfoliating skin on the plantar surface of the foot, but it may also manifest as dry, scaly lesions on the dorsum of the foot characterized by collarettes of scale (little scaly circles). The correct diagnosis can be confirmed by identifying fungal hyphae on microscopic examination of lesional scrapings that are prepared with potassium hydroxide (KOH) solution, although this is rarely necessary.

First-line treatment for uncomplicated tinea pedis limited to the skin is a topical antifungal agent, such as terbinafine. Other topical agents, such as an azole (clotrimazole, ketoconazole), can also be used, but studies suggest that allylamines (terbinafine and naftifine) have superior efficacy; both classes perform better than placebo.

In addition to using a topical antifungal, patients with tinea pedis should be advised to keep their feet dry and to use cotton or moisture-wicking socks that breathe sufficiently.

Key learning point: The first-line treatment for tinea pedis is a topical antifungal agent, such as terbinafine.

D) INCORRECT:

The use of 1% hydrocortisone, with an adjuvant emollient like mineral oil or other thick moisturizer, would be appropriate for atopic dermatitis, but it has little role in the treatment of fungal dermatitis and may worsen tinea pedis.

E) INCORRECT:

Mineral oil can be used as an adjuvant emollient in the treatment of atopic dermatitis but is not a treatment for tinea pedis.
questions.hint: This patient's symptoms and examination findings indicate a tinea infection.

questions.text: A 20-year-old man comes to the office because of a 3-month history of a rash on his groin. He describes the rash as intensely itchy and has noticed it growing in size over time. He is on the college wrestling team and says the rash is particularly uncomfortable when he sweats during practice. He has noticed a similar rash on a teammate's feet in the communal showers. His vital signs are within normal limits. A photograph of the patient's skin findings is shown. Physical examination reveals that the lesion spares the scrotum. Which of the following is the most likely cause of these findings?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Malassezia furfur causes tinea versicolor, a noncontagious cutaneous yeast infection most often seen in individuals who sweat excessively. This condition manifests with round well-demarcated finely scaling macules that can gradually coalesce into irregularly-shaped patches. Tinea versicolor most commonly affects the upper trunk (less commonly, the intertriginous areas). Lesions are typically hypo- or hyperpigmented but are occasionally erythematous. Furthermore, although tinea versicolor lesions can be mildly pruritic, they do not manifest with raised red borders.
Image Description:

Well-demarcated hypopigmented macules, that partly coalesce into bigger patches, as well as a fine branny scaling, are visible on the forehead of this child.

This appearance is typical of tinea versicolor.

B) INCORRECT:

Candida albicans can cause a cutaneous yeast infection of the intertriginous areas (e.g., the inguinal folds) that manifests with a pruritic, erythematous rash. Intertriginous Candida infections are often triggered or worsened by heat and moisture. While Candidal lesions usually affect the genitalia, this patient's lesion spares the scrotum. Affected individuals typically present with satellite lesions that raise suspicion for Candida, and the rash is usually moist, macerated, and homogenous rather than scaly with raised borders.
Image Description:

Localization: region beneath an obese patient's breasts

Lesion: sharply demarcated, red lesion with white maceration and satellite lesions

Description: chronic inflammation of intertriginous area due to sweat and warmth; bacterial or candidal superinfection highly likely

C) CORRECT:

Trichophyton rubrum is the most common cause of tinea infections, including tinea cruris. Tinea is usually spread through close personal contact (e.g., wrestling), communal showers and pools, and contaminated items like towels or bedsheets. Tinea cruris typically causes pruritus, which can be worsened by moist, humid environments (e.g., sweating during wrestling practice). This condition is treated with a topical antifungal (e.g., terbinafine), but in patients with advanced symptoms and/or immunocompromise, systemic antifungal therapy may be indicated. Preventative measures include wearing loose-fitting clothing, keeping the inguinal area dry, and avoiding the transfer of fungi from the feet.

D) INCORRECT:

Corynebacterium minutissimum causes erythrasma, a superficial infection of moist intertriginous or interdigital skin that manifests as well-demarcated brown or erythematous patches. Erythrasma is usually asymptomatic but may cause mild pruritus. Erythrasma lesions manifest with fine scaling and wrinkling of the skin rather than a scaling raised red border. C. minutissimum is part of normal skin flora and more commonly causes infection in patients with risk factors like obesity, diabetes, or older age.
Image Description:

Right side of the scrotum

Lesion: reddish-brown, sharply demarcated macula

Diagnosis: erythrasma

E) INCORRECT:

Staphylococcus aureus causes nonbullous impetigo, a highly contagious bacterial skin infection that initially manifests with erythematous papules that may be pruritic. The lesions gradually become vesicles or pustules that rupture, forming honey-colored crusts. Impetigo does not manifest with a scaling, raised red border. This condition most commonly affects the face (less commonly, the extremities) and is unlikely to manifest on the groin or inguinal area. Furthermore, impetigo is most commonly seen in young children.
Image Description:

A round, well-demarcated erythematous plaque with yellowish crusts is visible on the child's chin.
questions.hint: The photograph shows a well-demarcated erythematous plaque with scaling and a raised border, consistent with tinea cruris, a centrifugally growing rash.

Wet mount of scraped skin stained with 20% KOH solution, which dissolves keratinocytes. While this method makes fungal elements easily visible, it does not allow for differentiation between different types of fungi (dermatophytes, yeast, etc).

D) INCORRECT:

Scabies can cause pruritic, erythematous, well-demarcated lesions. However, the lesions typically manifest as elongated papules and scattered vesicles with burrows tunneled by the Sarcoptes scabiei mite and more commonly develop on the hands. Scabies does not typically manifest on the thigh as a solitary, erythematous, annular plaque with central clearing and a raised border.

E) INCORRECT:

Erythrasma can cause pruritic, well-demarcated lesions. However, the lesions are typically hyperpigmented, macular, and more commonly develop in intertriginous areas (e.g., the axillae and groin). Erythrasma does not typically manifest on the thigh with a solitary, erythematous, annular plaque with central clearing and a raised border.
questions.hint: The photograph shows an erythematous, annular plaque with central clearing and a raised border.

questions.text: A 27-year-old woman comes to your clinic with a complaint of a flaky, dry rash on the soles of both feet. On examination, you observe scaly, dry patches and collarettes of scale on the soles of both feet (figure). There is maceration and a superficial fissure between the fourth and fifth toes on the left foot. No other skin lesions are present, and the toenails are not involved. Which one of the following treatments is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: Mineral oil applied to the affected area.
Thick moisturizer applied to the affected area.

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The use of 1% hydrocortisone, with an adjuvant emollient like mineral oil or other thick moisturizer, would be appropriate for atopic dermatitis, but it has little role in the treatment of fungal dermatitis and may worsen tinea pedis.

B) INCORRECT:

Mineral oil can be used as an adjuvant emollient in the treatment of atopic dermatitis but is not a treatment for tinea pedis.

C) CORRECT:

Tinea is a fungal infection caused by aerobic dermatophytes that infect only the epidermal layer of the skin. Risk factors include warm, moist environments; shoe wearing; and exposure to affected individuals or to fomites such as exercise mats, locker room floors, bathtubs, or shower stalls.

Tinea pedis typically manifests as superficial maceration between the toes or as exfoliating skin on the plantar surface of the foot, but it may also manifest as dry, scaly lesions on the dorsum of the foot characterized by collarettes of scale (little scaly circles). The correct diagnosis can be confirmed by identifying fungal hyphae on microscopic examination of lesional scrapings that are prepared with potassium hydroxide (KOH) solution, although this is rarely necessary.

First-line treatment for uncomplicated tinea pedis limited to the skin is a topical antifungal agent, such as terbinafine. Other topical agents, such as an azole (clotrimazole, ketoconazole), can also be used, but studies suggest that allylamines (terbinafine and naftifine) have superior efficacy; both classes perform better than placebo.

In addition to using a topical antifungal, patients with tinea pedis should be advised to keep their feet dry and to use cotton or moisture-wicking socks that breathe sufficiently.

Key learning point: The first-line treatment for tinea pedis is a topical antifungal agent, such as terbinafine.

D) INCORRECT:

A thick moisturizer can be used as an adjuvant emollient in the treatment of atopic dermatitis but is not a treatment for tinea pedis.

E) INCORRECT:

An oral antifungal, such as systemic terbinafine or fluconazole, may occasionally be used to treat severe or refractory cutaneous fungal infections, or if there is involvement of the nails, but a topical antifungal is indicated for first-line treatment.
questions.hint: This patient's symptoms and examination findings indicate a tinea infection.

questions.text: A 20-year-old man comes to your clinic with a 3-month history of a rash on his groin. He describes the rash as intensely itchy and notes that it has increased in size over time. He is a member of the college wrestling team and reports that the rash becomes particularly uncomfortable when he sweats during practice. He has observed a similar rash on a teammate's feet in the communal showers. Vital signs are normal. A photograph of his skin findings is provided. On examination, the lesion spares the scrotum. Which one of the following is the most likely cause of these findings?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Staphylococcus aureus causes nonbullous impetigo, a highly contagious bacterial skin infection that initially manifests with erythematous papules that may be pruritic. The lesions gradually become vesicles or pustules that rupture, forming honey-colored crusts. Impetigo does not manifest with a scaling, raised red border. This condition most commonly affects the face (less commonly, the extremities) and is unlikely to manifest on the groin or inguinal area. Furthermore, impetigo is most commonly seen in young children.

B) INCORRECT:

Malassezia furfur causes tinea versicolor, a noncontagious cutaneous yeast infection most often seen in individuals who sweat excessively. This condition manifests with round well-demarcated finely scaling macules that can gradually coalesce into irregularly-shaped patches. Tinea versicolor most commonly affects the upper trunk (less commonly, the intertriginous areas). Lesions are typically hypo- or hyperpigmented but are occasionally erythematous. Furthermore, although tinea versicolor lesions can be mildly pruritic, they do not manifest with raised red borders.

C) INCORRECT:

Corynebacterium minutissimum causes erythrasma, a superficial infection of moist intertriginous or interdigital skin that manifests as well-demarcated brown or erythematous patches. Erythrasma is usually asymptomatic but may cause mild pruritus. Erythrasma lesions manifest with fine scaling and wrinkling of the skin rather than a scaling raised red border. C. minutissimum is part of normal skin flora and more commonly causes infection in patients with risk factors like obesity, diabetes, or older age.

D) INCORRECT:

Candida albicans can cause a cutaneous yeast infection of the intertriginous areas (e.g., the inguinal folds) that manifests with a pruritic, erythematous rash. Intertriginous Candida infections are often triggered or worsened by heat and moisture. While Candidal lesions usually affect the genitalia, this patient's lesion spares the scrotum. Affected individuals typically present with satellite lesions that raise suspicion for Candida, and the rash is usually moist, macerated, and homogenous rather than scaly with raised borders.

E) CORRECT:

Trichophyton rubrum is the most common cause of tinea infections, including tinea cruris. Tinea is usually spread through close personal contact (e.g., wrestling), communal showers and pools, and contaminated items like towels or bedsheets. Tinea cruris typically causes pruritus, which can be worsened by moist, humid environments (e.g., sweating during wrestling practice). This condition is treated with a topical antifungal (e.g., terbinafine), but in patients with advanced symptoms and/or immunocompromise, systemic antifungal therapy may be indicated. Preventative measures include wearing loose-fitting clothing, keeping the inguinal area dry, and avoiding the transfer of fungi from the feet.

Key learning point: Tinea cruris, a pruritic rash of the groin that spares the scrotum, is most commonly caused by the dermatophyte Trichophyton rubrum.
questions.hint: The photograph shows a well-demarcated erythematous plaque with scaling and a raised border, consistent with tinea cruris, a centrifugally growing rash.

questions.text: A previously healthy 16-year-old boy comes to your clinic with a pruritic rash on his chest that has progressively enlarged over the past 10 days. The rash is not painful. He is sexually active with two female partners and uses condoms inconsistently. He works part-time as a lifeguard at a public swimming pool. A photograph of the rash is provided. Which one of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Several dermatological diseases do not require treatment, such as pityriasis rosea. Pityriasis rosea is usually self-limited and can manifest with pruritic scaly plaques and a central clearing. However, lesions are usually preceded by a solitary pink or flesh-colored plaque (known as a herald patch or mother patch) and are not associated with raised borders. Patients with dermatophyte infections, such as tinea corporis, should receive appropriate treatment as well as advice on how to prevent spreading the infection.

B) INCORRECT:

Topical erythromycin is used in the treatment of acne vulgaris and skin infections such as erythrasma, which manifests as scaly, pruritic, hyperpigmented or erythematous patches. However, erythrasma lesions typically appear in intertriginous areas, such as the axilla or groin, and they are not characterized by central clearing.

C) CORRECT:

Topical antifungal therapy (e.g., miconazole, terbinafine) is the first-line treatment for most dermatophyte infections, including tinea corporis. Dermatophytes thrive in moist environments, and this patient works at a public swimming pool. Tinea corporis can be diagnosed clinically. In case of diagnostic uncertainty, suspicion of dermatophyte infection is usually confirmed via potassium hydroxide (KOH) preparation.

Systemic antifungal therapy (e.g., oral terbinafine) is used to treat dermatophyte infection in patients who do not respond to topical therapy, immunocompromised individuals, and/or those with extensive spread.

Key learning point: Topical antifungal agents such as miconazole are the first-line treatment for tinea corporis (ringworm), a superficial dermatophyte infection.

D) INCORRECT:

Topical hydrocortisone is used for a variety of cutaneous conditions, including psoriasis, allergic reactions, and atopic dermatitis. Topical hydrocortisone is not indicated as a monotherapy for tinea infections. In addition, topical corticosteroids should not be used in combination with first-line therapy for dermatophyte infections, as they increase the risk of adverse effects and recurrence compared to first-line treatment alone.

E) INCORRECT:

This patient's sexual history increases his risk for syphilis, which is treated with penicillin G benzathine. Secondary syphilis typically manifests with cutaneous involvement in the form of a generalized nonpruritic, scaly, papulosquamous rash. However, though the lesions can develop a central clearing, they are usually much smaller than those of tinea corporis.
questions.hint: A pruritic and slowly enlarging rash with erythematous raised scaly borders and central clearing is consistent with tinea corporis.
